185842189.review: I know that my steam account says I've only played 42 hours, but I've actually bought this game 3 times on disc before I got it on steam. It is one of my most played games. I strongly suggest you get mods as well after you've beaten the campaign and done some galactic conquest and instant action. The Ultimate Mod Pack Launcher is the best but can be hard to find. Top 5 best Star Wars games out there and easily one of the best video games of its time.

185678244.review: This game was my childhood. I spent hundreds upon of hours back in middle school playing through Rise of the Empire or Galactic Conquest or Mos Eisley Assault, on my own or in splitscreen with friends. Playing it again, it's just as amazing as I remember. PS2 era graphics aside, this game has so many immersive nods to the movies. Just about every inch of every level is taken from the films, even from throwaway shots you never paid attention to. All of the units and ships are the same way. The voice acting is top tier. The lines are beyond iconic. The music is John Williams' Star Wars score, possibly the most legendary film soundtracks of all time. The gameplay is perfection. The space battles are still the gold star standard that modern games with space battles are compared to. As are the various game modes, such as the previously mentioned Galactic Conquest or Mos Eisley Assault. Age notwithstanding, this game is a 10/10. Mandatory if you are a Star Wars fan, strong recommend if you aren't.

185621736.review: It's a classic; simple to understand, you can feel yourself getting better, and there's multiplayer. It doesn't get much better.

Anyway, if you've played it before, you'll enjoy it again. But if it's new to you, you'll enjoy learning the pros and cons of each unit and which works best for you.

185125121.review: This game is a lot more challenging or stressful than I remember it being when I used to play it on the PS2 with my brother. It has aged quite well though. The controls took some getting used to since again, I played with a controller not a keyboard, but once you learn it's pretty tight, and you can always rebind the keys. The action is fast-paced, having lasers and rockets fly past your head and explosions constantly going off and loads of troops on both sides running about the place is quite immersive. There are different factions reflecting the various sagas or eras and classes to choose from amongst them, each with their own loadout. There's vehicles available across the maps, both when you're fighting grounded on a planet or in space. If you perform well enough in a match, you get the opportunity to play a designated hero for a temporary time. There's a campaign, galactic conquests, instant action and multiplayer to play. Overall a very fun game and I'm glad I came back to it. The EA ones are missing something special that these classics have.

185103409.review: The most iconic Star Wars Battlefront game ever. Very fun to play even in 2025 - 20 years after release!

Installed it few days ago and it's still great! This game is from the time when developers made good, finished games! Amazing replayability! New games don't have even half game modes and features this game had! If you are for 2000s nostalgia and action game this is great! A lot of different troops, vehicles, starfighters, jedi knights, sith lords, a lot of maps you name it! Infiltrate enemy destroyer, camp with sniper, wreck havoc with Droideka...this game is endless fun!

184942244.review: Is it just me or are old Star Wars games the best? I don't really play this game much anymore, much like other games, but that doesn't change the fact that this is one of the best Star Wars games ever made. Growing up, I played this on PS2, and playing it on PC today is something else. Since the game is old, you can't play on the old graphics, but when you play this game on steam, you can mod the crap out of it which adds things like maps and improved graphics. The saddest part of this story is that the remastered version of this game that came out recently flopped. Why? The main reason why is because on launch there was only a few servers available to play on which meant that only a few hundred people could play at a time. That ultimately lead to the forever downfall of the game and that concludes my review.

184829894.review:
While I completely understand the craze for this game during its heyday, these days I wouldn't recommend it unless you're experiencing a strong rush of nostalgia. For me however, the game is not a fond childhood memory, because when it came out, I was already significantly older than I would like to admit. Let's face it:
[list]
[*]the graphics are completely outdated, and unlike some other games of this era, the gameplay, story, atmosphere and overall quality don't make up for it.
[*]I have never experienced a more brain-dead AI than in this game. While the computer-controlled enemies overrun you, your own troops hinder you or even actively push you into the enemy line of fire.
[*]the single-player campaign seems rather lackluster and haphazardly put together.
[*]the space battles don't even come close to the much older "Tie-Fighter" and "X-Wing" games.
[*]you shoot at enemies, hit them square in the face and they don't even get a scratch.
[*]the entire interface feels clunky, sluggish and outdated.
[/list]
On the other hand, it is "most impressive" that there is still an active modding and online player community for this game. And you can get this old game cheaply during a sale and try it out without sinking €30 into the half-heartedly re-released Battlefront Classic Collection.

Eventually I got a Xbox series X and had it in my library but almost never played it. But rolled around 2024 Christmas and got myself a laptop with an $80 gift card for steam. 184367181.review: I don't play online in general and I doubt there's many players on this title anyway, so my review is for single-player only. I think that this game is pretty depressing to be honest. Firstly, the graphics: the modern Battlefronts are visual masterpieces, but the graphics in the old ones are predictably bland, and unlike some old games the graphics don't have any character to make up for the limitation in technology. It's just low-res textures, dreadful lighting and blockiness everywhere. Secondly, the AI is clearly designed for console peasants using an analogue stick to aim. You target them and they just stand there shooting you without any movement whatsoever. Very engaging. Difficulty mode has no effect on this either. Not to mention that the controls feel stiff and clunky, unlike the modern Battlefronts. As with many games, I'm sure this was designed for console then released on PC as an afterthought, so the game tech isn't exactly what PCs were capable of at the time (PS2, likely the target platform, was released in 2000).

183834549.review:
If you experienced black screen while playing this game, it's likely because of Discord overlay. 

Go to Discord, click registered games in activity settings, you'll be able to find Battlefront 2 being listed there, and then turn off toggle detection and toggle overlay. I also experienced the black screen and it was resolved after turning off the Discord overlay.

My opinion about this game: Yeah it's good

183821064.review:
10/10

In short: 
Pros- no micro-transactions, not expensive, not 50+ gb, no sequel trilogy, good community, easy to access multiplayer, tons of gamemodes, maps, units, heroes / villains, mods and more.
Cons- Few bugs here and there regarding resolutions but can be fixed, no Xbox DLC though can be added back in through a mod.

In Full:
Almost 20 years later and this game remains king of Battlefront games, no micro-transactions, no ridiculous price tag, no fuss, and yet there's so much content to explore. It's an amazing simple game to pick up and have a blast, through Galactic Conquest where you capture individual planets and locations throughout the Star Wars Universe, through the Campaign where you engage in the events within a 501st Journal, or you simply just want to choose the map and rules within Instant Action. Multiplayer is alive, even more so than Classic Collection, and you get to choose the server you want to join through the server list, so getting into a server is even easier than the modern Battlefront's (probably going to get a lot of clown Steam awards for that but don't care). Also, Star Wars Battlefront 2 2005 can be played in both third person and first person for most units and vehicles.

Through a technological standpoint alone, this game is remarkable. This game has seamless dogfights to in-freighter combat within the space maps, where you can destroy the internal systems of said freighter. You could even steal a spaceship from the enemy freighter and land it into your own team's freighter, which while might not give you any advantage, goes to show how much freedom is presented within the game (on the topic of freedom, heroes / villains like Darth Vader can ride vehicles like Speeders, AT-AT's, etc, which in most Battlefront games is exclusive to the troops). This game offers multiple different gamemodes as well. In XL mode (exclusive to Kashyyyk, Hoth, and Geonosis since they're larger maps), the amount of present units per teams is majorly increased, and in hunt mode you can play as or fight against the indigenous species of planets throughout the Star Wars universe. This could be fighting the Geonosians as a clone trooper, destroying units as a Wampa, defeating droids as a Gungan and more. All of what I have mentioned within this paragraph is not present within other Battlefront games.

Each planet has its own vibe and conditions. On Polis Massa (an asteroid from Episode III), you will take damage when into the central space zone of the map when playing as any class other than the droids, which makes sense as droids do not require oxygen, furthermore showing the attention put into this game. In Jabba's palace, you'll find Gamorrean Guards attacking and attempting to take command posts on rare occasions. Each map has a different vibe from the last, making playing each map more worthwhile. 

Something worth noting is this game is less of a 'Battlefront' of trying to fully simulate what it's like being a trooper within the Clone Wars / Galatic Civil war, but rather the game is more of a power fantasy style game in how the AI isn't as aggressive to you compared to other Battlefront games. This is also a reason why multiplayer is so fun, as other players with potentially similar skill levels can fight against you and other AI (if the server isn't full then the match is pvpve rather than pvp). The only con with multiplayer is that the Dark Side (Empire / CIS) tend to have a better chance at winning as some people (you know who you are) tend to spam Force Choke, a Dark Side exclusive ability that is ridiculously OP as its victim is unable to move or defend, which hence definitely breaks the fun at times.

People also report a black screen bug, this is normally because they have Discord Overlay turned on, which tends to not work well with the game. Another bug that people find is that on certain maps (Examples include Kashyyyk, Dagobah, Yavin 4, some modded maps, etc) the water looks very odd, this is because the game doesn't fully support resolutions above 1080p, so to fix this either play the game at 1080p or less, or download the Shader Patch mod on Moddb (more on mods later though). Other issues that are caused by unsupported resolutions include small UI, Mission Select Screen not having a matching aspect ratio, some scopes causing half the screen to have a strange screenshot-esque picture. 

This game has a huge modding community as well, this is perhaps one of if not the Star Wars game with the most mods. The website to go to when searching for mods is ModdB, as that's where the largest amount of mods are for the game when on the internet. I would've given this game a 9/10 if it weren't for the mods, as the mods fix so many issues with the game and add so much more, whether it be new eras, gamemodes, maps, sides, etc. The main reason for the amount mods is that Pandemic's developer tools are available to be downloaded online (though I recommend the 2020 SDK over the original as the 2020 SDK fixes multiple issues when trying to create mods). Creating mods through these tools is super complex and sometimes doesn't end up right and so a large portion of creating a mod is trial and error. Yes I did create a mod of my own. Yes it's horrible. There are some truly talented modders within ModdB, so I do highly recommend attempting to go get some mods. For map mods you need an Addon folder within SWBF2 2005's Gamedata folder and then simply put in the three letter code folder of the map mod inside said Addon folder. Make sure you have the mod dependencies (if there is any), and I highly recommend getting Mod Loader since there is a 500 mission limit which if you exceed will cause crashes.

Well there's my review for my favourite game ever, so yeah. Stop reading my review and get / play the game.
